Setting up Jekyll

Jekyll  · 29 Mar 2019

I thought it would be easy to set up Jekyll, but in the end I still encountered a few difficulties.

Preserving my old Msc project pages

When I studied my Msc at UCL, I used Github Pages to host my research project on reading activities and the home. Originally I used Ghost to host the content and converted the content into static pages and host it on Github. However, I lost the database file for Ghost and could no longer update the blog. I still want to preserve the content as it is while finding a way to keep the site alive.

Using Jekyll

Recently I found Jekyll. With instructions from here, here, and resolving a few file conflicts, I was able to host it on Github Pages.

Running Jekyll locally on Windows 10

Setting up Jekyll on a Mac was painless, but it was a different story on Windows. It seems that Ruby (the language Jekyll is written in) and Windows are known to be incompatible. I followed the guide here to install Ruby on Windows 10.

Changing the theme

The default theme minima was frankly, not very pretty. I found the theme Garth, which met my needs. I forked it and resolved a few dependency errors, and it worked perfectly.

Solving a Unicode issue on Windows

When I switched to my Windows machine at home, I encountered an issue while generating the Jekyll blog locally. After some research, it turned out to be an issue with encoding. Following the instructions here, finally everything worked out.
